page.title: 06TRANSPORT IN THE BUSBY AREA
page.content: The main method of transport is by {private car}with 75% of households owning at least one car(compared with 45% in Scotland).During the peak hour (8-9am) 1,788 cars used the main commuter roads to and from Glasgow.As the roads are over-used there are plans to build a by-pass to the east. The two forms of{public transport}are bus and rail.The bus services are run by the Regional Council and by a subsidised company.This means in Busby there is a frequent bus service but only hourly to Waterfoot.Thorntonhall has no bus service. Busby and Thortonhall have railway stations on the diesel line to Glasgow.There is a half hourly service with more trains at peak times.There are plans to electrify this old line which is a single track south of Busby.
